OptimalBinningWoE 0.1.6.9006

Optimal Binning for Numerical Variables using Equal-Width Binning

optimal_binning_numerical_ewb.Rd

Performs optimal binning for numerical variables using equal-width intervals (Equal-Width Binning) with subsequent merging and adjustment steps. This procedure aims to create an interpretable binning strategy with good predictive power, taking into account monotonicity and minimum splits within the bins.

Usage

optimal_binning_numerical_ewb(
  target,
  feature,
  min_bins = 3L,
  max_bins = 5L,
  bin_cutoff = 0.05,
  max_n_prebins = 20L,
  convergence_threshold = 1e-06,
  max_iterations = 1000L
)

Arguments

target

Integer binary vector (0 or 1) representing the target variable.

feature

Numeric vector with the values of the feature to be binned.

min_bins

Minimum number of bins (default: 3).

max_bins

Maximum number of bins (default: 5).

bin_cutoff

Minimum fraction of observations each bin must contain (default: 0.05).

max_n_prebins

Maximum number of pre-bins before optimization (default: 20).

convergence_threshold

Convergence threshold (default: 1e-6).

max_iterations

Maximum number of iterations allowed (default: 1000).

Value

A list containing:

bins

Character vector with the interval of each bin.

woe

Numeric vector with the WoE values for each bin.

iv

Numeric vector with the IV value for each bin.

count

Numeric vector with the total number of observations in each bin.

count_pos

Numeric vector with the total number of positive observations in each bin.

count_neg

Numeric vector with the total number of negative observations in each bin.

cutpoints

Numeric vector with the cut points.

converged

Logical value indicating whether the algorithm converged.

iterations

Number of iterations performed by the algorithm.

Details

The algorithm consists of the following steps:

  1. Creation of equal-width pre-bins.

  2. Assignment of data to these pre-bins.

  3. Merging of rare bins (with few observations).

  4. Calculation of initial WoE and IV.

  5. Ensuring WoE monotonicity by merging non-monotonic bins.

  6. Adjustment to ensure the maximum number of bins does not exceed max_bins.

  7. Recalculating WoE and IV at the end.

This method aims to provide bins that balance interpretability, monotonicity, and predictive power, useful in risk modeling and credit scoring.

Examples

set.seed(123)
target <- sample(0:1, 1000, replace = TRUE)
feature <- rnorm(1000)
result <- optimal_binning_numerical_ewb(target, feature)
print(result)
#> $id
#> [1] 1 2 3
#> 
#> $bin
#> [1] "(-2.809775;-0.019709]" "(-0.019709;0.910313]"  "(0.910313;3.390371]"  
#> 
#> $woe
#> [1]  0.01987743  0.03562919 -0.12833957
#> 
#> $iv
#> [1] 0.0001916461 0.0004367342 0.0028105280
#> 
#> $count
#> [1] 485 344 171
#> 
#> $count_pos
#> [1] 242 173  79
#> 
#> $count_neg
#> [1] 243 171  92
#> 
#> $cutpoints
#> [1] -0.0197092  0.9103126
#> 
#> $converged
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $iterations
#> [1] 18
#>
